content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Double Fin Productions offers a fun little role playing game, but its simplicity can be its one flaw. The simple combat makes Costume Quest seem rather dull, but the interesting story, amazing concept, and the crazy costumes create an epic game. Costume Quest:This game tells the story of a family who move to a new town right before Halloween. Their mother sends her two children out to trick-or-treat: Reynold and Wren. You get to choose to play as either one of these two children, but after the start of the game whoever you don’t choose is taken away. Your mission is to retrieve the other sibling and save this town from the monsters who are trying to destroy Halloween forever. Grubbins on Ice:Grubbins on Ice is the expansion for Costume Quest which extends the story to enter the world of Repugia. Continuing the tale that Wren, Reynold, and their friends started this expansion offers a summary. The Grubbins are experiencing a takeover by an evil crew of monsters who are raising the taxes and steeling the candy. Can you save the foes that originally caused you so much distress from a fate worse than death, a world without candy. Gameplay:Just beat this game, other than the final boss on Grubbins on Ice being slightly challenging the overall game was incredibly easy. This game has a fun an interesting story which makes me wonder if all that occurred was just a child’s imagination or in fact was supposed to have really happened. The game drifts between reality and fantasy creating a world through the eyes of children. The game offers elements of questing, puzzle solving, and combat all without a single bit of bloodshed. The gameplay is interesting, but incredibly simple. The characters wear costumes which allow them to enter into battle with their opponents gaining the power of their outfit. The costumes have one attack and ability. No matter which costume you where the basic attack is essentially the same (doing the same amount of damage only visually different). The costumes differ based on their special ability, which makes each costume slightly unique. Results:If you are interested in an RPG that’s not a page turner, but rather just a fun little side project then this may be for you. This game has simple gameplay, relatively easy to follow plot, and very basic questing; all which adds up to a game which you can play for a while, put down for a while, and come back to without feeling like you lost a beat. Overall it’s a fun little game that doesn't offer too much on your plate, but just enough to fill you up. Pros:+Simple basic combat system which requires no real skill+Friendly characters and interesting story line.+Relatively friendly controls+Very basic puzzles which require not mental skill.+Good game for all ages as there is no gore or inappropriate dialogue. Cons:-Gets very repetitive-No replay value. Once you have completed this game there is no reason to try it again (which is fine if you can get this game at a good discount)-Cannot cycle through characters and thus must play as the first character in line; this can be really annoying if you want to quickly cycle through costumes rather than continually opening the menu to change the costumes between characters. Which results in you then have to change the costumes back to the previous setting if you want your main character to wear a specific costume for its exploration ability.

Posted: November 16, 2011
												Perfect for Hallow'een yet I love this game and will play it any time of the year! Costume Quest is one cute game with quirky humour and the style reminds me of Nickelodeon type cartoons. I found the gameplay to be easy and repetitive like most RPG games, in Costume Quest this is easily excused as it is all about levelling your characters (A bunch of mischievious kids!) trick or treating and knocking on doors, creating and finding new costumes, collecting battle cards to enhance your characters and most of all, collecting candy! Costume Quest is two games in one, you can play the normal Hallow'een storyline, then afterwards the sequel: Grubbin's on Ice, which has a winter orientated theme. If you have kids they will love this game, if you are a big kid at heart, yes you will love this fun little game too!

content:
Posted: January 13
												I really enjoyed this game because it really captures a lot of the fun of the Halloween spirit that can be so easily ignored in favor of Christmas, especially for us adults who don't get much to do on Halloween unless we want to go to a bar or club.  Starting off, I'd say what builds this Halloween concept so well is all of the different nods to Halloween activities throughout.  This ranges from the bobbing for apples mini-game, collectible cards you can trade and swap for, gathering random household objects to build different costumes, going throughout different areas in town to attend various events (costume contest, various neighborhoods, etc.), dealing with a random bully/jerk, and of course going Trick-or-Treating.  I thought it was fun going to random doors, not knowing if you would receive a treat, in the form of gobs of candy, or a trick, in the form of a random battle.  A nice variation on the random battle aspect you normally get in RPGs.Battles are fairly straightforward and simple, with different costumes providing the player with options on which combat style and ultimate move they prefer to use.  Don't like trying to time your attack or hit the right button prompt once it appears on screen?  Then you will likely have an alternative to use instead, once you unlock enough costumes.  Sometimes different combat situations will require the player to mix and match to get the right combination, but since this game lacks grinding (since enemies don't respawn) there is always some way to get through your current fight.  Early and mid-game fights were sometimes hard to get through since I'd need to avoid making any mistakes (especially when going against 3 baddies at once), since it was so easy for them to just kill off one of my guys and make it so I couldn't win the fight at all.  Otherwise though, I saw nothing wrong in the combat as it had just the right balancing, for me at least.The game has fun and witty dialogue, which compels the player to explore and talk with various NPCs.  Sometimes navigating the map can be a bit annoying, but once you get the hang of it it's not too bad.  It does help having the robot roller skates on to zip around at turbo speed, a thankful addition since most games like this have you plod around at a constant speed.  You even get to pick between being the boy or girl, without one or the other being obvious eye "candy." *pun intended*Overall, I would recommend this game.  It doesn't offer much for replayability, but it's worthy of a full playthrough.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												Costume Quest is a really wonderful and fun adventure for kids and adults, who still remember how it's - be a kid. It's simple, funny, touching, it's make you laugh a little and smile a lot and there aren't many things, that can do so, so I appreceate the experience. You should know though that the game is very repetitive: rob some shop, fight with monsters, do it again and again. Still, it doesn't mean that Costume Quest aren't enjoyable - quite the opposite actually, but I just give you warning.Now for the main part: it's a Halloween adventure and we have two siblings, who want to celebrate and take all sweets for themselves. They are boy and girl, it's your choice who you want to play with (hint: the choice happens, when your mother decide who will be in charge). But quite quickly events become much more difficult - the big green monster steals your sibling and now you HAVE to find him\her. Or take the wrath of your mother. Monsters just don't look so scary now, come to think of it...Gameplay is very simple: you must take sweets from shops and homes, you must fight monsters that come your way and take some side quests and exploration if you like. It may sounds boring, but actually it's pretty fun because of battle system, story and dialogs. Battle system looks like a Dream world, where your nice costume (i didn't mention this? Come on, the game has a "costume" in title!) becomes a powerful weapon. Like, robot costume transforms into actual fabulous robot. There are also ninja, Statue of Liberty, Space warrior, magic unicorn... and french fries. Where else you can fight with your enemies, using your french fries powers?! Okay, to actual battles. Little warning: you need some reaction for this, because you will need to quickly press some buttons while you attacking or defending to make better results. And yeah, each costume have it's own special powers for battle. Like, healing allies or making a powerful attack, or shielding the ally or yourself. It's your choice what combination to prefer (hint: you aren't all alone, there will be friends, some from the very beginning, some later).As for the story, I just don't want to spoil it for you, but it's wery fun and enjoyable with all jokes, references for popular culture, dantists's twist plots... You'll see many absurd situations and many exapmles of wonderful wrinting. Seroiusly, it's good and not only for child's taste. I highly recommend to complete every quest and talk with everyone - dialogs are pretty hilarious here, really, you will have a good time. So, if you are kid in your heart or at least can be, try the Costume Quest. Despite all its humorous self, it tells a story about siblings, about people, who may fight and tell a pretty bad things, but they're still family. They still love each other, even if it take a monster invasion to understand such a simple fact. And if you still wondering: of course adults don't help children to fight monsters. When they ever did? *sigh* Adults.P. S. If you encounter sudden perfomance problems (characters move very-very slow), try to reboot your computer. Strange advice, but it helps me.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2013
												The trailer for this definitely does not do it justice. I heard quite a few times this game was really good, and after watching the trailer numerous times over a course of forever and thinking that it looked terrible, i brought it anyway seeing as it was on sale. And I’m glad i did, this game really is amazing and the trailer doesn't do it justice at all.You play a small child, who is in fact a twin. You pick your twin (female/male) and then the story unfolds. Your parents let you out to trick or treat one night on Halloween, but due to a turn of events you find yourself trying to rescue your twin. We all know children have vivid imaginations, and this really throws you back into the mind of a child. The "combat" in this game is amazing. You have various different costumes you collect along the way, and these are you're ultimate weapon against the bad guys. It’s extremely fun, you use abilities and do quick time events to beat your enemies and the friends you make along the way builds your team of defence, each having their own abilities which with the right combinations can make really good teams.Going into the combat mode really reminded me of when i was a kid, back in the days where i watched power-rangers, it was a great experience, and i really enjoyed it.Like most of Double Fines games, there are various things to collect to make the game that little bit more fun for people like me that just can't resist collectables. It was yet another DF game that i just had to complete 100%, achievements and all. And it was sad to see it end.It’s definitely worth a try, don't let the trailer put you off, it really is worth both your time and your money.

												So, I watched the video, looked at the screenshots and figured this might be a good game for the kids but I'll never get around to playing it....boy was I wrong!  Upon giving it a go I was stunned to find an incredibly simple yet thoughtful and FUN (remember when games were more fun than work?...well that is Costume Quest in a nutshell) game that provided a good few hours of entertainment and the closest the kids made it to the controller was watching Dad play as this is a game that I just had to devour all of the content for.The combat system is ridiculously simple for all bar a couple of big boss fights (which had me thinking about team dynamic and offensive/defensive strategies) but it was only starting to feel too repetitive as I was nearing the end of a full play through for 100% in a day.  A great game, well worth the money, love changing costumes - it's fun & I even found myself taking screenshots to look back and enjoy the costume battle transformations :)

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												Double Fine is a bit like Pixar. They bring a certain magic and charm to all of their products. Most of their games are quite humorous and the stories are creative and unpredictable.So if Double Fine is Pixar, Costume Quest is Double Fine's "Cars." It's not a bad game. The premise is nifty and the jokes will make you grin, but there are just better showings if you want the Double Fine experience. Costume Quest takes place on Halloween, and you are a kid who has to rally some friends to trick-or-treat your way through town to save your sibling. It's colorful and delightful, like playing an old-school Nickelodeon cartoon. But after about an hour the old school Nickelodeon is overshadowed by the old school RPG game mechanics, which are repetitive and don't provide much actual decision-making or challenge. The story is divided into three beautiful set pieces, but again, the game play in each set piece is identical. Same main tasks, same exact sidequests, and the costumes you collect for monster fights aren't varied enough in their abilities to matter.If you love Double Fine and you're very tolerant of JRPG-style gameplay, you'll probably have fun, but I wouldn't make this your first Double Fine game. Psychonauts is the one to go with.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2016
												I almost bought Costume Quest 2 this past sale -- before playing Costume Quest 1, which I've had in my library for quite some time. I'm glad I didn't buy the sequel which is billed as much of the same. After playing Costume Quest 1 to 100% completion, I have no desire to ever revisit it or play the sequel.Is it a bad game? No, but I wouldn't recommend it unless you're a fan of turn-based fights with QTE-like button presses. The art style is cute, the Halloween theme whimsical, the story is sufficient. However, the turn-based combat with unskippable animations gets very old very fast. In addition, the surprising lack of voiceovers is very disappointing; the game's story and interactions would have been much improved with spoken dialog.If you're on the fence, watch a few Let's Play videos on YouTube in order to get a feel for the plot and the combat. My mistake was simply buying on the strength of the studio (Double Fine) and the majority of positive reviews. All-in-all, I'd say the game is like Halloween candy: it's sweet but ultimately will make you sick if you have too much of it.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Ahh, Tim Schaffer's company "Double Fine" creates a "light" RPG adventure game revolving around kids and Halloween. Crossing the style of South Parks "Fun with Weapons" episode with Final Fantasy, the powers come from the costumes that each wear. A Robot with strengthened attack power, a knight with heightened defense, the statue of liberty with powers to heal the whole team. There are a total of around 9 costumes, but each only has one "ultimate" power.The ideas behind the game are great, the setting really puts the player in the minds of the children, how they think- even there is no voice acting, the feeling and emotions are brought out wonderfully.Story lacks depth, idea being that some witch or other is stealing candy to help her get to some other country where she can take over. It felt something that a kid thought up. At the start of the game, your twin gets kidnapped, and this is the only time I ever felt any kind of real connection to it.The art-style reinforces the setting of playing in a kids world, big eyes, very cartoony.Gameplay is either adventuring around looking for cases, hitting anything for candy (even getting candy from trash cans!), or spent in the battle sequence, where very "Final Fantasy" style gameplay commences. Unfortunately, both modes get old very quickly.The adventure part feels like a very "dark" Zelda game. It's not bad, but not great either. There were times where paths were too difficult to be seen, or understood. Finding the cases in the Mall, or even the hill on the final stage, where I thought fallen trees had stopped me walking up. (took me 3-4 hours just checking online as I thought it was a bug, or checking if I missed something). "Trick or Treating" became old in the first half of the game with no variation, which brings me to the...Battle sequence. This is where the action happens. Unfortunately, each costume only has one ultimate, as stated earlier. Also each person has one "battle stamp", which gives them a "counter", "stun", etc. Basically one trait that helps the character regardless of costume worn. Like the adventuring part, this becomes very stale from the second stage and begins to feel just like a waste of time for the player.All in all, for the experienced RPG player, this is very lack-luster. An even SIMPLER version of "Final Fantasy Mystic Quest" on the Super Nintendo comes to mind. So for children, this game would be a great purchase to introduce them to the genre of RPG.Other reviews stating that this game is "too short", may be correct. But with so little variation with Gameplay, AND a lack-luster story, I'd have to say it's a little too long.Pros:The universe is nice and well brought out by its use of graphics and sound / music.Great ideas put on the table.Nice bits of humorCons;Adventure sections too dark and sometimes difficult to navigateLacking gameplay and depth, game gets old very quickly.Overall;I give this a very average 50-60%It feels that with all of the great ideas that were put onto the table, about half of the potential was made. I'm not sure if it was a rushed project or anything, as the music and sound was perfect, but it would be nice to see what would have happened if the developer had gone the extra mile.As it is, I can only recommend this game for younger gamers who you'd like to introduce the RPG genre- outside the world of Pokemon

Posted: December 12, 2014
												CQ is another great game from double fine.The story follows a brother and sister as they attempt  to save their little town from monsters at halloween. It is all told through the use of "speech bubbles" around key characters. The game is pretty reminiscent of JRPGs, but without any specific classes or skills, just leveling and different constumes with different abilities. When playing the game, you're penned in to one of a few key areas. These areas are pretty large though, so there's always a fair amount to explore, such as finding hidden coffins [rather than chests], and quests to complete. When you encounter a monster, you'll be thrown into a fight scene very similar to those used in JRPGs. I've played this game with a controller and with keyboard/mouse. Given my experiences, and the fact that this was originally for consoles, I would definitely recommend using a controller to play it. However, keyboard/mouse also works well.The 3d model graphics are very cartooney, but very good as this fits well with the concept of using speech bubbles when characters are talking. They give a very nice impression of the "feel" of halloween. The design of the kids is also very good, although there could have been more diversity in the adult characters. It would have been nice if the camera wasn't locked in to a specific angle, however.The soundtrack to this game is simple and not very overbearing when you're in the environment, which us good, but the music during cutscenes can get a bit repetitive. There is a distinct lack of voice acting, and I did feel that the game was a bit let down by this lack, but this didn't detract too much from my enjoyment. You may be in trouble if you can't read speech bubbles.This game includes both CQ and it's DLC "grubbins on ice". GOI is much of the same high quality, but set in winter.CQ is a very good game, if quite short. It's not extremely challenging, but it has a very good story and art style. Definitely worth playing if you want a simple JRPG type game, or are a fan of double fine.

Posted: March 26, 2014
												It seems that Double Fine can do no wrong, IMO. During Brutal Legend's troubled time with no publisher, Tim Shaefer let the leads on that project brainstorm with their own smaller teams. Tasha Harris, Brutal Legend's lead animator, pitched the idea for Costume Quest and THQ gave it the greenlight and here we are with a great family-friendly turn-based RPG adventure game sugar-coated with a fun Halloween theme.Setup: you are one of two fraternal twins in a new neighbourhood and you have to go out and make friends on Halloween. Your NPC brother/sister dresses up as a candy corn piece and is promptly candy-napped by a goblin (called Grubbins) and you along with new friends take off through your neighbourhood, the mall, and eventually to the Grubbins' world to rescue your sibling.Mechanics: combat employs a very basic turn-based RPG engine with quick-time events to bolster your attacks/defenses a la Super Mario RPG (press X at the right time to defend, match the on-screen commands to do extra damage, etc).There is a 'collection' aspect to the game as well in the form of stamps that you can apply to your costume as buffs, granting you extra active/passive battle effects. Mini games and side quests scattered throughout the different locations are fun diversions that are key to getting all of the aforementioned stickers, money (candy--it's Halloween after all!) and other consumeables to use in battle.You will also find random items that when combined with a 'design', form a new costume that can be equipped by any member in your party. Each costume has a special attack/support action and by mixing and matching, you'll definitely find a combination that suites your style of play.The original story and Grubbins on Ice campaigns together have a decent length. I can't remember how long I spent completing them and Steam didn't log my playtime since I played the entire game while at sea with no internet connection (damn you, Steam achievements!) I actually had to boot it up again to play for at least 5 minutes before Steam would let me post my review.. makes sense.I'll just use it as another excuse for a second playthrough, probably around Christmas time ;)TLDR: what you want, Cliffs Notes?

												I love this game! I was looking for something to get me in the mood for Halloween and this was perfect- cute, spooky and full of little details and secrets. There are lots of side-quests and things to collect along the way, which appeals to me a lot. The costumes and battle opening sequences for each costume are really well done. The one thing I struggled with initially was the mechanics during battles; you have to press the specified key at exactly the right time to execute a successful attack or defence which took me a while to get my head around! After a while, though, I found this aspect to be enjoyable and the difficulty curve was just right, I think. All in all I loved playing this, and would definitely recommend to those who like cuteness, collecting things and really well decorated Halloween scenes :)

Posted: October 8, 2016
												Like all Double Fine games, this game is unique and well worth a play.  The characters are cute and celebrates the spirit of childhood imagination.  This is essentially in JRPG style where random encounters are replaced with trick-r-treating door to door with monsters lurking in some of the houses.  The various costumes are fun to experiment with and require different timing mechanics when attacking. Posted: October 27, 2014
												Costume Quest is a really cute, short, turn based RPG set on Halloween. Your sibling has been taken by monsters after they mistook her candy-corn Halloween costume for real candy and you set out on an adventure to get her back.On the way you unlock various costumes which transform into the “real thing” in battle. 												Simple, charming RPG. Lighthearted story, if rather simplistic and borderline repetitive, but not long enough to warrant complete burnout. Posted: December 12, 2014
												CQ is another great game from double fine.The story follows a brother and sister as they attempt  to save their little town from monsters at halloween. It is all told through the use of "speech bubbles" around key characters. The game is pretty reminiscent of JRPGs, but without any specific classes or skills, just leveling and different constumes with different abilities. When playing the game, you're penned in to one of a few key areas. These areas are pretty large though, so there's always a fair amount to explore, such as finding hidden coffins [rather than chests], and quests to complete. When you encounter a monster, you'll be thrown into a fight scene very similar to those used in JRPGs. I've played this game with a controller and with keyboard/mouse. Given my experiences, and the fact that this was originally for consoles, I would definitely recommend using a controller to play it. However, keyboard/mouse also works well.The 3d model graphics are very cartooney, but very good as this fits well with the concept of using speech bubbles when characters are talking. They give a very nice impression of the "feel" of halloween. The design of the kids is also very good, although there could have been more diversity in the adult characters. It would have been nice if the camera wasn't locked in to a specific angle, however.The soundtrack to this game is simple and not very overbearing when you're in the environment, which us good, but the music during cutscenes can get a bit repetitive. There is a distinct lack of voice acting, and I did feel that the game was a bit let down by this lack, but this didn't detract too much from my enjoyment. You may be in trouble if you can't read speech bubbles.This game includes both CQ and it's DLC "grubbins on ice". GOI is much of the same high quality, but set in winter.CQ is a very good game, if quite short. It's not extremely challenging, but it has a very good story and art style. Definitely worth playing if you want a simple JRPG type game, or are a fan of double fine.

Posted: December 4, 2013
												Costume Quest is a simplifyed turn-based RPG where you must trick or treat the various houses in the levels in order to advance, gain different costumes with abilities and stats of their own and buy special skills for your party.The title isn't that challenging nor requires an intense grinding: if you fill your candies buck on a regular basis and buy the right abilities you will have no problems in any of Costume Quest's battles. Being able to answer well to the various combat QTEs (which you can use both to defend yourself and inflict extra damage per attack) is however mandatory.Beside fighting in random battles and collect candies and equipment, there are also several side quests in every area: the majority of them is recycled once per level, but without feeling that repetitive. Given this is a Double Fine game, you can also make a personal quest out of witnessing the various NPCs chatters and reactions.The main appeal of Costume Quest is the writing: the story is simple enough, but the humor of the various NPCs and situations make up for it quite nicely. And of course, there are various videogame references for your to find.The Steam version of Costume Quest also comes with the only DLC for the title, Grubbins of Ice. This new chapter doesn't add anything new to the overall game's formula (save for three new costumes) and doesn't last that long, being worth an average of two hours or so. However, as with the main campaign, the new jokes and characters make Grubbins on Ice a worthy add

Posted: October 20, 2016
												Fun little pick me up that's less than *AHEM* on *AHEM*. It's seriously a fun RPg that reminds me of Paper Mario: The Thousand Year Door with it's battle system (Only that it has action commands), but there are some pros and cons to it.For one con, it's much harder if you can't do action commands, so for example....Say "Grubin" attacked and it told me to hit the E button. If I don't hit the E button then, I get hurt slightly more.However, if you can survive the battle, you auto heal after every battle, and losing doesn't make you load, you simply have to restart the battle. So really, there's no real concequence to failing in battle besides the humility of being defeated by a filthy grubin.But even the enemies have personality, even though some of the people in the games may not be the nicest, they're still extremely well made. One con about the NPCs however, is that they overuse the same NPC around the different places you'll visit. (SPOILERS AHEAD) And besides bosses, there's only three types of enemies, and three species of enemies you'll fight, with maybe two or three I missed. Three types, one for each species, makes 9 different varients besides bosses. However, now to think on the bright side, there's some nice humor in the game that made me let out a 'ha!' every once in a while. I did NOT get my copy on *AHEM*, however, I payed the full 10 dollar asking price (Or I might have gotten it on sale on Steam, I don't remember), but however much I payed, I believe it's worth my money entirely.7/10, a good game for an okay asking price.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2016
This is the best game I have ever played!It has AAA graphics and state of the art anti-aliasing(FXAA).Everybody is composed of big potatoes, which is a very original and brilliant design idea, congrats to the devs!The story is extremely gripping, the heroes are awesome, the battle mechanics are the best I've seen. Clearly current AAA studios should borrow more from this game.The sounds are beautiful, and thankfully they continue playing even after closing the game. The music is a catchy little loop, which is repeated all over the game.  I love that this game does not allow you to change your resolution to foolish ones(e.g. 1920x1080) and instead crashes when you try to mess up your resolutions. There are two types of houses:One where you can find very strange bakugan, which can multiply instantly, and one where you can find kind humans giving you lots of candy.When you engage in battle with the bakugan, you can watch a pleasant little cutscene where your heroes turn into transformers and you can use many unique abilties to fight: attacking and blocking.The fight system utilizes the keys E,SHIFT,SPACE.Quick time events are used and explained perfectly, the gameplay designers sure had loads of skill.Thanks for this excellent game for not a cent more than 10 euros.I know for sure, that this game will reshape the gaming industry altogether.11/10 Made my life worth living.Thanks for this masterpiece, developers.

												While not the best Double Fine game out there, Costume Quest is a simple, casual, adorable little turn based RPG.I'll tell you the truth, I'm not a turn based RPG fan, but I did enjoy myself with this one - it's not too long, combat is pretty casual and straight forward, and the game can get challenging at times.During this adventure you will recognize a lot of Double Fine's humor and creative design. Posted: April 7, 2015
												The Paradox's review on: Costume Quest NOTICE: Verdict on bottom of this review. My quick notes to the devsWhere to start...  first, I must say that I got this game by a coupon and stumbled apon it quite randomly.  I MUST  say that this game is  AMAZING!  This game brought out my inner childhood of pretending that I was a Jedi or a ninja on halloween and you guys put all of it in a game! One of the best games I've ever played! Thank you Double Fine! Summary Costume quest is a cute animated game that is a turn-based RPG Halloween game! Your goal, to save your (brother or sister, your choice) from the evil candy stealing Grubbins! You may free-roam around the (actually) large 3 areas that the game provides you to search for your sibling, collect battle stamps, trading cards, costumes, Trick or Treat (A MUST :)), battle Grubbins, and find new friends! There is all sort of neat little things that the creators put in for you to find for yourself! The dialog is absolutely a belly-rumbler and the controls are crisp and easy to use! At the end of  Costume Quest  the creators decided to throw in the DLC Grubbins on Ice which adds on to the orignal quest and is also quite entertaing as well! If you are a teen or an adult, this game will surely touch your childhood in one way or another! The good!  Controls are on point for this game, even with a controller! The graphics are very cute and clean! This game his it's own style on graphics and runs very well on  ANY  Computer. Gameplay and storyline gets right into action immediantly and never declines in action during the whole game! Although the game does not come with voices, the dialog is quite funny! Very good setting! Music helps improve the mood and the atmosphere. No doubt makes up for the lack of in-game voice-overs. A rare game that brings yourself and your memories alive! Achievements are real easy to achieve if you finish the story carefully. A  TOTAL  bang for your buck! The Bad!  Although dialog is good, in-game voices would help A short campaign and DLC will only put you at about 20 hours to 100% completion. Familar battles may get a bit annoying, but no too much. The  Ugly  AMAZING A rare game that brings yourself and your memories alive! The Verdict Overall this game is amazingly entertaining and fun to play for all ages! While the game may have a few minor flaws, like no voices and it's length, it makes up with no doubt with good graphics, sounds, entertaining storyline, neat details, and epic quest! It's a must have in your steam library! Good job Double Fine! Post-Game Stats  Graphics: 9/10Audio: 7/10Plot, Storyline, and character builds: 10/10Controls: 10/10Entertainment: 10/10Overall: 9.5/10FINAL: Must Have!THANK YOU FOR THIS AMAZING GAME! -CaptainParadox

content:
Posted: January 21, 2012
												Costume Quest is a carefully distilled J-RPG with a well written, light hearted story and solid gameplay. It's a good pick-up-and-play game in a genre that usually requires days of investment, with likeable characters and just enough depth. Normally, quick-action sequences ruin the pacing of a game for me, but they are well implemented here in a way that feels almost intuitive, if still a bit repetetive, after a few battles. When the main storyline wraps up, the included Grubbins on Ice add-on storyline lets you start with all your stuff from the main quest, and includes new costumes (character classes) and stamps (bonus abilities). I'd recommend this for kids or adults who don't need dimension-spanning save-all-of-time-and-space plots, ridiculously complex leveling systems, or spiky-haired, ambiguously gendered anti-heroes in their J-RPGs.

Posted: August 7, 2012
												Don't let the Saturday morning cartoon art and story fool you (this game is not really suitable for most young kids), this is pretty close to an old school turn base JRPG, albeit a lite version. Think FF3 with it's job system and a dash of QTE for DMG/DEF and you get an idea of what to expect. Finding the right combo of costumes and battle stamps that compliment the party is key (to boss battles mostly), although I did find one combo that was a little to OP. Also fast QTE reflexes can be a boon for survivability.That said, sadly since it's not a high budget game, it's pretty short and not very deep in story and the battle system, but all in all it was fun and I had more than a few good laughs. I literally had a smile on my face the whole way through. So, if you like old school JRPG gaming and enjoy silly/zany cartoons do yourself a favor and check it out.

Posted: November 2, 2016
												Costume Quest is a Halloween themed JRPG-like game made by Double Fine Productions.This game is about a quest to save your sibling by fighting, trick or treating and getting apples from the barrels without using your hands.During your adventure, you will get different costumes and stickers that will somewhat allow you to change the flow of battles.Each costume got its own special attack or support moves, stickers are acting like changeable buffs and basic attacks involve different quick time events (depend on the costume) in which a successful QTE will score a critical damage and allow the combat to progress faster. This game is very fun, though gets reparative halfway through the game, I would still highly recommend it for the story and it's humor.

Posted: November 4, 2016
												Probably the cutest game Double Fine has ever made, with a fantastic premise and decent execution. It's short but the length is nice for what it is, there are numerous laugh-out-loud moments with the dialogue, the environments are detailed and look quite nice, and the plot, while simple, is pretty enjoyable. The game is very easy in terms of its turn-based battles, so if you're looking for a challenge, look somewhere else. I do think it works very well as an "introductory RPG", though, and can be used to teach newcomers to the genre about basic RPG tactics like prioritizing enemies, diversifying your party's classes, making strategic decisions about abilities, and choosing when to use special moves so they will be most effective. A solid game that makes for a fun Halloween night.

Posted: November 10, 2016
												Costume Quest is very different from any other Halloween game I've ever seen. It's not a simple "BOO! Happy Halloween!" game that you find on Google's homepage. It's a full on RPG with a charming artstyle, great music, fun gameplay, and a lovable team of monster slaying children (seriously, the idea of putting on an adorable costume and then transforming into the the actual thing it was based off of was an epic idea :P). If you're sick of playing horror games during the Halloween season and just want a cute and fun game to play, look no further than Costume Quest!

Posted: November 12, 2016
												Costume Quest is one of my favorites - unique and dripping with the innocence of halloween most of us are too old to experience anymore, it's the type of game that makes you smile on its premise and presentation alone. Throw in fun - if simple - game mechanics, good humor, endearing characters and a plot out of a saturday morning cartoon: it's a really good package, and as something I can replay every year, it's more-than worth the TEN dollar asking price.At its core it's a super simple turn-based RPG, but even its RPG mechanics have fun mechanics much like those from the original Paper Mario. You can fare better in battle with timed button presses to increase damage and defense. There are battle stamps that work like the badges from Paper Mario, which give each character a boost or a special command. It's really not that deep, but the fights are just difficult enough to require some kind of strategy. Not because they're complex or anything, but because the enemies will simply overpower you with force if you don't have a battle stamp equipped and aren't successful with the timed button presses.For example - the Statue of Liberty costume has a special attack (which charge up through using regular attacks) that heals the party a small amount. It's a very small amount, but it can make or break a fight. The game is good about pitting you against enemies that are just a little bit tougher than your party, so you can't just breeze through them. There are also no random battles: all enemies appear on the screen, unless you meet them through trick-or-treating, and they don't regenerate - so there is a set number of battles per zone. This works well with the mechanics, as there are set items and experience you earn from the enemies you fight. That means you really must fight every enemy in the zone to get the full amount of experience, candy (currency) and items afforded to you. You move between transitional dungeons and hub zones, where you have to trick-or-treat at houses or stores to progress through the story. You won't be able to do that all right away, though - you'll need to do random quests for kids around the zones, collect candy, bob for apples, trade stuff, and find parts to make new costumes which grant you new field abilities, so you can progress further. The zones are really detailed and oozing with character - they're fun to run around and don't usually outstay their welcome. My only gripes are without a map, it can be hard to find that one last house you need to trick-or-treat at to progress the story, or that one last enemy you need to fight. Also some of the dungeons drag on a little bit - but as I write below, if you're finding the game to drag, you probably just need to take a break.The plot is simple - your sister is kidnapped and you have to find her. There are goblins running around, but the adults think they're just kids in costumes. The goblins want candy for some reason, there's a main villain witch, etc. etc. It's really cute, and serviced by some great humor. The game is almost south-parkian in the way that the kids have gotten over their heads in a very real situation to which the adults are totally oblivious. It makes it funnier when the adults names are all literally "grown up". Costume Quest is a game to play in small spurts, as otherwise the mechanics will begin to get repetitive and you'll lose sight of the charm and atmosphere that makes the game so enjoyable. When I say repetitive, I mean the combat and actual field exploration can, yes, get really samey. It's best to play maybe half a zone at once and then take a break. You really owe it to this game and yourself to enjoy every minute of it, and that can't happen if you're just going through the motions. Costume Quest is a gem. It captures the feel of Halloween perfectly and if you're in the right mood, it can make you feel like a kid again. Like you really are out trick-or-treating with some friends, in a world of make-believe. Buy this, play it (during halloween), and then play the Grubbins on Ice DLC (that comes with it) during Christmas. I haven't actually played the Grubbins on Ice DLC yet, but I've heard great things about it. Albeit - it's a short little extra side-story that only take a few hours.

Posted: October 24, 2015
												This is a SUPER cute and charming RPG. It's short but sweet, the battles are pleasantly paced and aren't random, and it's got a lot of personality and funny dialogue. The battles have a lot of quick-time events, but you can generally afford to whiff them, and it adds a nice "visceral" feel to the flow of combat. The battle system is simple, but still engaging, and there's a decent variety of costumes to switch between. I also appreciate the music and the art style and the lack of voice acting. Has some nice puzzly aspects to it too. Exploring and collecting candy and bashing everything with your Halloween bucket is very addictive and satisfying.And the free DLC, Grubbins on Ice, is a great addition that adds another, say, 2 hours to the game in the form of a new area to explore that continues from the base game.Overall, if you have an RPG itch you want to scratch but without having to dump 70 hours and endure long introductions/expositions/worldbuilding, or if you want to get into a festive mood, this is a simple and fun game for that. This is a perfect example of an RPG without a bunch of padding, short, sweet, simple fun, and a good game for all ages that really captures the spirit of Halloween and childhood imagination.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I didn't know exactly what to expect when I installed Costume Quest. I was a big fan of Tim Schafer games when I was a kid (Grim Fandango and Full Throttle are some of my favorite 90s video game memories), but found Double Fine ventures like the much-loved Psychonauts to be marred by either clunky gameplay or hideous art decisions.  But Costume Quest proves that Tim Schafer's still got it, and within 20 minutes I was a fan again.Sure, the game doesn't employ high-end graphical techniques, the traditional JRPG style combat moves can take too long, and the game is quite short. It doesn't have a "deep" story, and doesn't really try to say much, either. But the subtley perfect art, the cute-but-not-sickeningly-so character designs, and witty dialog overcome any shortcomings.It's not complex, but it's one of the most "perfect" games I've played in years.Recommended to anyone with good taste, and essential to any gamer who remembers what the 90s was like.

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This is an adorable take on the standard turn-based RPG. As sweet as its subject matter, Costume Quest puts you in the shoes of a fourth grader who is tasked with rescuing his (or her) sibling from the clutches of a villainess whose evil schemes is going to wreck Halloween.The game features standard RPG fare such as leveling up, hit points, and turn-based combat. Instead of classes you don costumes which grant you special powers, which can be augmented with special battle stickers.I loved the art style, the humor, and the fact that I have a game about trick or treating. My only quibble was that combat was too easy, with the exception of the final boss in Grubbins on Ice, I don't think I lost a single battle. But this is probably due to enemies not respawning. So, instead of a standard JRPG where you're forced to level grind for hours against a never ending horde of enemies, you need to discover the perfect balance of costumes and battle stickers amongst your party to succeed. In this regard, I feel that Costume Quest is a very newbie friendly RPG.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2012
												Costume Quest is a cute little casual game with a great sense of humor. Although the gameplay is very simplistic and the fighting system is fairly boring the short game length and funny dialog makes it forgivable.The game starts you as an aspiring trick or treater. Unfortunately disaster strikes when your sibling is abducted by goblins and you have to go rescue him/her. The game plays quite simply, you have to goto various house to trick and treat which gives you candy, the game's currency. You battle goblins and other monsters as you go along and through completion various quests you unlock new costumes.The combat plays quite simple. Yourself and 2 companions go into battle each wielding a costume that will grant them different powers and you then take turns attacking the enemies until one side is killed off. Each costume has only one regular attack and one special move they can perform every three turns but to try and break up the monotone a little each attack requires you to perform a quicktime event to maximize your damage.The graphics are fairly simple but the style is sharp and the locations have a great Halloween look to them which really helps. The sound and music is nothing impressive but it doesn't detract anything from the experience either.All in all it's a cute little that gives you a few hours of fun however the simple gameplay and short length means it's only worth getting as a bargain title.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I've first played Brutal Legend, and now Costume Quest. Once again, Double Fine leaves me with mixed feelings.Costume Quest seems to be the kind of game I would enjoy a lot when I was a kid! Essencially, you're Reynolds, and it's Halloween. In the midst of trick-or-treating, there are monsters, stealing all the candy, who ended up kidnapping your sister. So, you put on your most badass costume and go look for her, fighting the monsters with the aid of your costume's powers, along with some friends you meet along the way.That sounds like something I would enjoy immensively when I was younger! And I still enjoyed it today, but it's not quite my kind of game.The game is a mixture of an adventure/platformer game, with a JRPG(ish) type combat. In combat, each character has a normal attack and a special attack, which takes turns to recharge. Instead of simply choosing which attack you want, there's also a QTE event that you have to do in order to boost your normal attacks. Each costume the character wears influences their attacks, and have a very unique style to them. There are also stickers you can collect while exploring the world, which will then give you a passive or active ability in battle.You have from 1 to 3 characters, and the same with the enemies. Each team has their attack turn, until the battle is finished.I didn't find the combat system very deep, with the exception of the Boss fights, which sometimes required a certain ability to be beaten, making the player experiment with the different costumes until he beat it. That was cool, but other than that, it felt a bit too shallow.To its favor thought, animation was top-notch, and every attack made you feel like a badass doing it.Outside of combat, you go around collecting candy, sometimes from door to door, other times just in the environment. You also interact with NPCs, with a very DoubleFine-esque dialogue which is always welcome. You have 4 zones (3 in the main game, 1 in the DLC), each with its theme, and a group of side quests. These side quests help the player explore the world, and also provide rewards. I didn't find them particularly interesting, but they were on the way, so it did not detract from the experience. I just think they could have done something more with those sidequests. There are quite a few "secrets" and Easter Eggs hidden around, making exploration quite rewarding to do as well!Besides, you'll need to explore to find different costume parts, which is the best part of the game, since each costume has its twist wether inside or outside of combat.The various costumes reminded me of some 90s cartoons, and others were just Halloween themed. They didn't every feel out of place. A good concept well implemented!The graphics aren't fantastic in terms of fidelity, but it's DoubleFine, so you know what to expect! They're highly stylized and unique, giving the game exactly the vibe they were looking for.Music was up there as well, really enjoyed it!Most of the achievements were mainly there to get the player to actually go out for the sidequests and different costumes so they're pretty standard... But, there was one about a Stacking Easter Egg as well. Nothing noteworthy, but it had a few achievements that could lead the player into a better direction when playing it, so that's good!So... due to the combat's lack of depth, it often felt a bit too repetitive, and so did some of the sidequests, since they're the same style for each zone. I get why it is like that, but since I didn't find them very interesting, having them in each zone felt a bit repetitive as well.But that's my biggest complain with this game. Other than that, I've had a blast with it, specially with the Boss fights! The game isn't very challenging (if it seems so, you're doing something in the wrong intended order, which happened to me), but it doesn't leave too much space for failure. Still, with its combat system, one couldn't expect anything too strategical.It looks and sound great, it's definitely an unique game, which takes you about 6-9 hours to finish, without and with DLC, respectively. It's not something I'm likely to go back to, since I've finished it, but it was a good experience nonetheless. It's a streamlined JRPG, with a twist!I'd definitely recommend it if it catches your attention at all. Great game, DoubleFine strikes again!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2014
												Costume Quest is a classic RPG with turn-based combat mixed with Double Fine style. You play a child out on halloween teaming up with other kids and fighting monsters, all while trick-or-treating.  Instead of the usual RPG equipment, the halloween costumes you wear transform into full size versions during combat, providing their associated powers to your characters.  It all meshes together perfectly, as you would expect from a Double Fine game.I'm not sure what else there is to say.  It's cute, charming, and a solid RPG experience that doesn't feel dull and repetitive like many of these types of RPGs do.  My only complaints are that the controls are a bit sluggish and the game is locked at 30 fps which will hopefully be addressed in a patch now that Double Fine has the rights to the game back.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2015
												So before I start, THIS GAME IS MEANT FOR CHILDREN!! And I'm recommending it on that behalf, If you are a hardcore gamer THIS GAME ISN'T FOR YOU.Story (8/10)The story isn't bad for a children game, but it's a bit lame for older audience. A kid saves his sibling on Halloween night. a bit long and unrealistic (for one night), but it's fiction, so who cares. As an adult I liked the story at the beginning, but for a game meant for children it wasn't that simply put and the lack of audio narration makes a barrier between the child and the story.Sounds (6/10)This is one of the worst aspects of the game, and the reason for that is the lack of narration or sounding for the characters.In a game heavily based on story with a lot of dialogues, FOR CHILDREN I think that is a huge problem. What takes me 7 secs to read might take a child 1-2 mins to read, and that's a deal breaker.Other than that, the game has good in-game music, and atmospheric music when entering some danger zones made a good time for me, and I think will more for a child.Graphics (8/10)For a casual children game, the graphics are very good, I won't say they are mind blowing ones, but they are colourful enough to catch children's eyes, and decent enough for this type of games.Gameplay (8.5/10)I think the most interesting aspect of thi game -for children- is the gameplay. It's way complicated than the ordinary children game, but it's way simpler than a MOBA or RPG. I think this game might be a nice introduction for children to use controller (I haven't used one to test it to be honest). Also there's a lot of side objectives those are pretty interesting and the different interactions between different costumes (although it's not that great of a deal) may be one of the most challenging aspects for children.If I have a kid and I want him/her to start hardcore gaming this is where I might start.BUT... it's so repetitive in fights that for a hardcore gamer it'll be extremely lame. so be aware of that.Overall (7.8/10)If you are getting this game for a kid, I think it's a good gift, just be aware of the repetitiveness of it. And the kid may suffer because of the dialogue if the kid reads slowly. Other than that, the game is good. It has sequel that I haven't played so I don't know how much it has improved, but I hope they have fixed the issues I mentioned.I'll definitly recommend it for a child.P.S. I say this again... If you are hardcore gamer that only enjoys AAA games you shouldn't even consider this one....

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Take the worst Paper Mario game you can think of. Remove all of the items, character skills, partners, and so on. Limit your party to only one customization badge each. The combat is now reduced to only "attack", "run away", and "limit break".No specific enemy types to regret using a specific move on, no special properties to watch out for, just straight up hit, be hit, and occasionally get the rare opportunity for a one-shot heal or all-enemies attack, for hours on end.Sound like fun? No? Well somebody thought it was a good idea and made it anyway. That's this game. And sadly, this is one of the last games DoubleFine has made that was actually "decent" in any way, shape, or form.

content:

 An amazingly cute turn-base rpg with charming designsThis game is just to cute that it deservs a lawsuit, my heart almost melted of joy, not just for its charming level design, but for the storyline too.The story is pretty much about two brothers(twins) that only want to have THE best halloween of their lives by filling their little baskets with treats, sadly they stumb upon a candy theft operation set by a witch and her group of creeps who wants to steal all the candies to feed an evil lord, so she can be granted passage to their world.But an halloween wouldn´t be an halloween without good old Trick or Treat right?In this game, you dont just fight monsters, you are also able to knock doors and say the magic word for some extra sweets, but what i really REALLY love in this game is the dialogs, its funny and just adorable, also these kids have some balls, i remember being scared of monsters and adults in my childhood, but these kids face danger head on with cute foul languages, its funny to see them pick on each other.Definitely a must buy if you´re into turn-based, RPG or just down cute adventure games, i promise you wont regret it.Money well spend.

												Fun and cute little rpg game. Recommended for those who just want to play an rpg without the huge time investment.Pros:-Cute-no grinding required (unless you want to 100% the game, and even then very little grinding is required)-short-lovable cast of characters-interesting dynamic where you're not really pigeon holed into making each character follow a specific role, lots of room for variation and you can always switch up your stats/abilities.Cons:-short, only took me 9 hours to 100% the whole game-movement can be a bit janky, I got stuck on the environment a lot-dialog is slow.Overall I recomment this game to anyone who just wants a short casual style rpg with a cute factor.

Posted: October 31, 2014
												Well after playing the game for a while I had to change my recomendation because I was lost in it's Cutzi ways. Well sometimes it was a bit to tough for my taste but only because I misunderstood the battelstamps, you have to assign one for each character or they do absolutly nothing. So it is an easy and charming game with some twits and nice sets of ceneries. So in all if you look for a satisfying game that is just like a vacation from all the hard games around here, pick this one. Expecially if you search for something cute to play over Halloween.The Negative Aspects:The problem is that the controls feel stiff, and that is pretty rare for a PC game. It feels more fluent with a controller with analog sticks but it is ruined by the quick time events. While in the keymenu where you can rebind the keys they are labeled with 1, 2, 3 and 4 and so on (Also some keys are not bindable and just bindthemselve as they feel like) in the game they are indicated with xbox360 controller keys. Which makes this game impossible to play with a PlayStation controller or any other not xbox360 controller, (except maybe an SNES controller but no analogsticks so the stiff feeling is back). And you may think, it can't be that bad with the keyboard, well you have to precisly manouver trough seom ramps while speeding up.Also I am very disapointed that there are no voice actors. I mean it is fine but the text scroles to fast and also the big bubbles block the view.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												If you're a fan of RPG's and Halloween, then this game is a must play. I played and beat this back when it was released on PS3. In spirit of this year's Halloween, I decided to play it again. I was surprised that the expansion campaign was added for FREE, kudos. This isn't some complex RPG, but merely an ode to when we were kids. Imagine how a kid feels and sees the world when he's wearing a cardboard robot costume, only to transform into a huge robot in battle that can fire missles! It's a cute idea and implemented well. That combat system is very simple, but it'll keep your attention since you need to complete various tasks such as "press button X" at the correct time. Small sense of accomplishment when you finally gather all the materials for a new costume and test out their special attacks. Took me about 8 hours to complete, still very much worth the 2nd time around. A kid would have a blast with this game, yet it is also for the adult that is also a kid at heart.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Costume Quest is a charming, heart-warming, hilarious, and well-crafted game. It is a nice little semi-RPG romp that can be completed in about 5 hours. The graphical style is extremely pretty and atmospheric. The sounds and music conjure up whimsical spookiness. The writing and story is superb, always giving a laugh yet pushing you forward. The gameplay consists of fun exploration around locales, attempting to trick-or-treat and also find all the secrets. There is also a fun but simple JRPG turn-based battle system implemented with wonderful “epic” battles on gorgeous set pieces. The only downside to speak of is that much of the dialogue automatically forwards itself, resulting in many missed lines unless you are a speed reader. Also, none of the dialogue is voiced, but that is only an issue because of how easy it is to miss certain lines.Overall, the game so perfectly captures the spirit of youthful exuberance and the pursuit of much candy! I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a fun, charming, and memorable experience!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2011
												Adventure/RPG-lite where, on your quest to save your little sister, you must find patterns and components used to make over a dozen costumes with useful battle powers and overworld effects that will get you further in the game.  You'll knock on doors and defeat baddies for candy you can use to buy powerups, bob for apples and eyeballs, and complete quests to earn rewards from the townsfolk.  Battle takes place on another screen where your characters are morphed into giant awesome versions of their costumes and combat is turn-based with timed button presses for bonus attack and defense. Difficulty is quite casual, but enough that your costume and powerup choices do have an effect on the outcome. Fun game to 100% and get the achievements for and a great port apparently because I didn't even realize it was a port.  The graphics are nice; didn't even have AA set up and someone asked me how I got AA working in my screenshots.  The game's about 6-8 hours long with DLC included.

content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
												It's simple, addictive, short and sweet (pun intended) If you're looking for a compelling story, raw challenge or innovative game play... please look elsewhere.This game is meant as an introductionary game for RPG noobies. It takes elements from Mario RPG / Paper Mario with timed attacks, so the game tricks you in to thinking you're doing more than selecting "Fight" from a menu. The costumes are fun to change up, half of them are useless and impractical but they look cool.The challenge does ramp up a bit at the very end and the final boss can be very obnoxious if you don't bring a healing costume in with you. If you enjoy games like Final Fantasy for it's job system and Paper Mario for it's timed button strikes, you'll enjoy this game.Only downside is how slow the game can be at times, having to watch repeated animations over and over before a battle begins... also it can be a tad clunky especially when using the dash feature from the Robot costume... This brings me to final point that it was bad game design on Double Fines part to allow this costume to dash and none of the others... It makes it manditory for you to utilize this first costume at all times meaning it doesn't give you much in the way of variety... Thankfully this was fixed in CQ2 with an actual dash button.The DLC Grubbin's on Ice is around the same length as one of the in game core chapters, 2 hours in length. Worthy addition to the game and links the events of CQ1 and 2 so it's basically manditory to play if you intend to continue your Costume Quest. :P

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Costume Quest is a charming, heart-warming, hilarious, and well-crafted game. It is a nice little semi-RPG romp that can be completed in about 5 hours. The graphical style is extremely pretty and atmospheric. The sounds and music conjure up whimsical spookiness. The writing and story is superb, always giving a laugh yet pushing you forward. The gameplay consists of fun exploration around locales, attempting to trick-or-treat and also find all the secrets. There is also a fun but simple JRPG turn-based battle system implemented with wonderful “epic” battles on gorgeous set pieces. The only downside to speak of is that much of the dialogue automatically forwards itself, resulting in many missed lines unless you are a speed reader. Also, none of the dialogue is voiced, but that is only an issue because of how easy it is to miss certain lines.Overall, the game so perfectly captures the spirit of youthful exuberance and the pursuit of much candy! I highly recommend this game to anyone who wants a fun, charming, and memorable experience!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 5, 2013
												Great adventure/FF-combat hybrid from the amazing people at Double Fine. It is to Final Fantasy (and adventure games) what games like Deathspank are to Diablo: simplified, humorous, and story-driven derivations. Costume Quest may not necessarily be the hardest game out there, but it is thoroughly enoyable all the way through. Especially if you have fond nostalgic memories of trick-or-treating.The free dlc/expansion called "Grubbins on Ice" that comes with it is also fairly good (it is a sequel, so play it after), however I feel much of my personal enjoyment of the original game came from the accurate recreation of what Halloween used to feel like. I still think there is plenty of room for sequels, but I'd personally like to see a return to Halloween in a town as the primary theme next time. Neighborhoods still have a ton of room they could grow in terms of varying atmosphere and style, so I wouldn't say a sequel back in town would feel redundant.Both the original game and the expansion are full of DF-style humor, as well as lots of side tasks to keep you entertained. This is not a massive game, however, and can be 100% completed in less than ~8 hours (much less if you skip all the cutscenes). Still definitely worth the money, as the experience will leave you satisfied and wanting more.Also, as a diehard DF fan there were a few fantastic references (the Psychonauts shop music at the mall, the Stacking dolls in the mountains), not to mention all the pop-culture jokes.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2011
												The premise of this RPG from the makers of cult classic Psychonauts is simple: You are a child whose halloween night is ruined when your twin sibling is abducted by monsters. In order to save them, you must utilize your never-explained ability to transform into whatever thing you are costumed as. Mecha, unicorn, vampire, a big box of french fries.. there's quite a selection to pick from.The combat itself is simple, traditional turn-based RPG fair with minor quick-time elements to get the most out of your attacks (and the least out of the enemy's) clearly intended to be accessible by players of any age, but anyone will enjoy the dramatic visuals and Double Fine productions brand of humor. The game's length is short, enough to occupy a couple days or one extreme halloween marathon. I finished the main content in six hours, and the included expansion in another two and a half.Expect to see the game on sale again next halloween for the pre-sale price of a big bag of candy.

content:
Posted: August 12, 2015
												This is essentially a casual RPG for kids, but I'm reviewing it anyway as an adult.Costume Quest is a very short turn-based RPG, but the highlight of its features are what it doesn't have. It's devoid of pretty much any interesting game system. The slim turn-based combat system present is similar to the Final Fantasy games, but you'll get more depth out of Final Fantasy games or 99% of their copycats. All of the combat uses Quick Time Events as well, which gets old after the second or third combat encounter. Game balance is simple and a little skewed. The game can be difficult (but hardly) when you only have two party members, and its trivially easy once you have three.The overworld is linear. There's a tiny bit of exploration to be had, but not much. There are roughly four quests in the entire game, each repeated several times for each phase of the game: find a card off a monster (combat encounters), bob for apples (simple mini-game), trick or treat houses (random combat encounters), and find six hiding kids (semi-hidden on overworld).The game crashed a few times, and since there is no manual save feature at any time, I lost 15-20 minutes of progress each time. The game plays the same every time.There are costumes to get, which are your battle suits or "classes". Variation here is only relevant in the costume's "special ability" but the game is so easy that once you have three party members, battle strategy matters little.Graphics meh, sound meh, witty dialogue is OK but not astounding. No voice acting.I don't recommend this game. You can find much better games in all of its genres for cheaper.  If you insist on wanting it, it's worth $2-3 on a sale perhaps. My playtime says 16 hours but that included a long idling session by accident. It's a 5-7 hour game. I'm surprised this game has a sequel. It's popularity seems dependent on the Double Fine brand, which hasn't been the same for me since Spacebase DF and the Broken Age Kickstarter mishandlings.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												Although Halloween have passed this is game that must be played, and would say going to 'trick or treat' would be funny and challenger. So Costume Quest is a Action RPG with a nice concept on it. As you guys already figure it this game takes place on Halloween, where two siblings, Reynold and Wren, will go ask for candies. The player at this point will choose which sibling to play as. One of the siblings will be kidnapped - depend what siblings you choose - and our missions is to find out her he/she is. During our mission, we will make some quest, and personally this was the worst part for me, because the quest are always the same. Costume Quest has 3 levels, the neighborhood, the mall and a carnival, and on all level the quest are the same, go ask for candy, do eat apple game, find some cards, get the costumes, find kids playing hide-and-seek, same thing happens on the DLC despite the level design is different. But if you put that behind your backs the game is really enjoyable, the game's graphics are a cartoonish style - thing that i love - and are well designed and very colorful, Costume Quest is more than colorful, is nice piece of art! The neighborhood and the others locations can make ous dive on feeling, is like we are on Halloween. And since is a Halloween Theme we will have lot of costumes to wear. Now to get the costumes you need to, get three different materials. When we get the costumes, besides changing our appearance we can go through places we didn't can before and will also gives special skills to use in battles. This battles can arise in two different ways, when you are searching for candy's or on street when you find a troll. When such things happens the scenario will completely change and your suit power will be activated, the battle style is a turn-based + quick time events.  When you do three attacks you will have a change to make the special attack, that can be a offensive or defense move. The special attack will be different according to the suit you are wearing. Since this is a RPG make sence we get XP for doing things, well when you complete the quest, defeat the trolls you will get some XP that will raise your level as well your defenses and your attack. Besides, you can buy in-game booster to help raise your attack and defense, although this is not very important because your enemies don't give a strong fight. Although this is a soundless game, contains a decent amount of humor there, some nice jokes and the dialogues between the characters is funny to read too. Costume Quest really grabbed me from the moment i installed, so is totally recommend! ~ 8/10

content:
Posted: October 30, 2015
												Just a very boring game. It lack any real depth.  Combat gets stale very very quickly. Story is just mediocre, tried-and-true. Items, a staple in any RPG, for whatever reason is omitted, where Double Fine could have added some 'tongue-in-cheek' elements. The only faint sense of utility or customizations is from the 'Battle Stamps", which are 'added bonuses' like an extra skill or stats, which seemed meaningless other than the counter-strike or stun skill -- the only one which would give me a chance in battle.The costumes did not offer any stat changes other than the obvious battle mechanic changes. Personally, I was expecting the 'knight' to have a more 'tank-like' role in addition to the 'shield' ability like More HP and lower attack. I'm expecting some differences. You can find yourself very easily overwhelmed in a 2v3 battle with no 'usual' / 'crutch' mechanic to swing the battle in your favor like Items or some OP one-time use ability. Instead you are greeted with persistent in battle costumes (which could have been changed like that of FFX-2 dynamic) and 1 every three turns "super-skill" that aligns with the costume chosen. Oh, and the battles consist of you pressing a button to do more dmg or take less damage.I got as far as the mall and just couldnt careless. The story is unique-ish, but the gameplay is just boring and rather... lame.

Posted: October 20, 2011
												Such a charming game. The graphics are cute and, even though the gameplay is the same as pretty much all the other RPGs, it still feels refreshing. Why ? Because most of the battles are based on trick-or-treating. And the gear you can collect are Halloween costumes. It's a cool idea, I really enjoyed it. But it does get repetitive near the end (it's about 5 hours long); the quests are the same in every new area. Apple bobbing, card collecting, finding hidden kids. It's a great game, but I just wish there was more variation.Still, if you love RPGs, or charming games in general, this is a must play.[Rating: 86/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Costume Quest is a charming, fun take on the turn based RPG genre. Sort of condensed. Instead of individually swapping weapons, spells, attacks, and actions you choose costumes that change your appearance, battle abilities and attacks, and help solve free roam puzzles with various actions. On top of that you can choose one additional action or buff for each character and swap them as you choose. Instead of finding and swapping party members you can instead choose their costumes. It really is sort of a "My First RPG", which may sound dull to an adult but it works well enough to engage. My one issue with this system is that there wasn't enough difference between the costumes to incentivise change. You are forced to change to solve some puzzles but I would always switch back before a battle. The battle system is turned based and pretty simple with only a few options each turn. This style lends itself to a little repetition but I tended to enjoy them since they typically don't drag on. One twist (Maybe, I don't play a lot of turn based RPGs) is that to land more powerful attacks you have to complete a QTE. There are several variations but each attack only has one. Things like press at a certain time, wiggle a stick, or repeatedly tap a button. Personally I didn't find that it detracted from the experience and actually makes sure you're paying attention to the battle and lets you contribute in some way. In true Double Fine fashion the writing (literally because there is no voice acting. Not a problem, just a statement) is top notch. Funny, witty, and endearing with jokes for both adults and children. Don't write off Costume Quest because of its apparently juvenile theme, you'd be missing out. It's fun, funny, and really is a nice departure from what you've probably played last. It doesn't over stay it's welcome and is well worth your time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												Costume Quest is the journey of a few kids to find as much candy as they can on Halloween (and  maybe  save one of their sisters along the way...  if  they feel like it). It's innocent fun that conjures up feelings of nostalgia that I'm sure we can all relate to, while positively radiating with a pristine aura of charm and joy. Now if all that doesn't already sound appealing to you, there are also a ton of innuendos and jokes that only adults can connect with strewn throughout.This journey should take you around 5 hours to complete, even if you seek to obtain every single collectable. It's definitely a pretty brief game, but I still really enjoyed my experience with it.If you're willing to let the kid inside of you out for a bit of fun, I'd say this game is worth  at least  one playthrough.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												I don't want to hate on this game. I love the story. I love the characters. I love the dialogue. I love the art style.I hate grindy JRPG combat.Where 75% of your game time is spent in combat, it should be engaging; not a throwback to the NES era. After my fourth fight, I found myself avoiding enemies whenever possible. Not because of the difficulty, but because each fight is another 2-3 minute delay from that quest item that I was looking for in the game world. I challenge anyone to convince me that this style of combat makes the game fun.If there were a quarter as many enemies, and you used puzzle-solving to overcome them, this game would gel a lot better.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2011
												Costume Quest is an amusing, anime style, adventure game with some unique dynamics. Firstly, costumes you pick up become useful in the game world in two ways. One, they each have a unique ability, like the robot costume to boost your speed and let you jump off ramps, and secondly, they become genuine fighting equipment, changing your character into what the costume represents. Be it a knight, or a fancy big robot, the costumes have incredibly power in this fun and quirky game by the creators of Psychonauts. Definelty a fun little game to play, and a get a fresh taste of Double Fine on PC.
